abstract.p: Patricia Hval letter on May 14 article disputes North Stonington Selectman Nicholas H Mulane's opposition to federal recognition of Mashantucket Indian Tribe (S)

block.p: It seems that the North Stonington Selectman, Nicholas H. Mullane II, (''Another Round of Questions Aimed at Pequots,'' May 14) would have found it acceptable if federal recognition of the Mashantucket Indian Tribe had meant only federal aid -- if the tribe, in other words, had remained poor and powerless. That the tribe has become rich and influential is, to him, unacceptable.

History teaches us over and over again that when oppressed or minority peoples begin to define themselves in their own terms and to gain power within the dominant culture, there is always a backlash. In this country, African-Americans, Chicanos, women and all Native Americans can attest to this truth.

Mullane II, (''Another Round of Questions Aimed at Pequots,'' May 14) would have found it acceptable if federal recognition of the Mashantucket Indian Tribe had meant only federal aid -- if the tribe, in other words, had remained poor and powerless. That the tribe has become rich and influential is, to him, unacceptable.

History teaches us over and over again that when oppressed or minority peoples begin to define themselves in their own terms and to gain power within the dominant culture, there is always a backlash. In this country, African-Americans, Chicanos, women and all Native Americans can attest to this truth.
The Mashantucket Tribe has simply become too uppity.
